dialogues.text: She knew herself. She knew her terms. How she wanted to live. (beat - morbid humour: ) Dad's attitude was, there’s only so much a juice cleanse can do. Saroo smiles at it.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: And what was your attitude?  54 A pause, as Lucy considers the question, and comes up fin with the only possible answer - here in the present:

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: I miss her. You can see in her eyes how deeply this is true. Then she glances up at him, changes direction, deflects it:

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You miss yours? But Saroo himself has about eleven force-fields around hi

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: I guess.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: What about your dad?

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: He walked out on us. Took another wife. Lucy shakes her head - crazy world.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Any brothers or sisters?

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: Two brothers and a sister. It was a long time ago. All a bit vague. He casually shrugs it away, as if the length of time is sufficient explanation for the vagueness. And then: SAROO (CONT’D) But there’s Mantosh. In Tassie. He’s adopted too. They walk.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So what do you think of Bharat’s search radius idea?

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: (ironic enthusiasm) I think it sounds promising. Saroo nods, but it’s noncommittal, a little distant.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You all right?  55 Saroo looks vulnerable; then suddenly he grins, and head- bobbles to her - Indian Style.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh my god. You are so wrong! And suddenly, shaking himself out of the past - playing t Lucy - flirting with her - Saroo pulls a few dance moves, mock-Bollywood style. Lucy laughs, embarrassed but impressed. And even though i momentarily playful, they both know that something deep h connected them. INT. SAROO’S STUDENT APARTMENT - LATER, SAME NIGHT Saroo, alone in the dark - despite the spark with Lucy, s rattled by whatever it is the jalebis have opened up in h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're in that mythic, prehistoric, dust-shrouded landscap WORKERS all around load rocks into old wooden hods. Saroo is running across the rubble, white with dust himse Everything heightened and surreal.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: Ammi! Ammi! [Mummy! Mummy! ] Kamla comes into focus, as she stands, and turns. But before we get to her, we -

dialogues.speaker: HARD CUT BACK INTO
dialogues.text: INT. SAROO’S STUDENT APARTMENT - CONTINUOUS (NIGHT) We can just make out Saroo’s face, as he sits in the dark

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: (whispers) Ammi ... Ammi ... The pain of memory. A sudden intense expulsion of breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wall of music. The BAND, sweating, pulsing, lost in the frenzy of instruments. A CROWD of dancing people. Saroo and Lucy, sweaty, tranced, deep ... their eyes lock a different kind of connection - visceral - almost alarmi They ride the music. Now a change of mood - the music shifts - haunting.  56 Saroo and Lucy hold each other up, enjoying the public intimacy. Their eyes meet - they hesitate - - this is real, the connection between them - - to surrender or not, that’s the question - - they go for it. Hand to hand, forehead to forehead -— - again, a mirror - physically connected this time. A transformative moment - - their senses, so alive - - so close, blurring into one. INT. SAROO’S STUDENT APARTMENT - NIGHT E/C/U: Saroo runs his finger slowly along the lines on Lu marble white arm and palm. WIDER: We’re in a tender post-coital darkness. Lucy drifting into sleep.

dialogues.speaker: MEMORY, FOREST, KHANDWA
dialogues.text: Sounds of the forest. Laughing children. CLOSE on 5-year- Saroo, facing a tree, his hands covering his face, but grinning through his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: Here I come! ... He turns. Beaming. Pretending to look here and there. SAROO (CONT’D) Where is she? Where could she be? HIDING, Shekila tries not to squeal with anticipation. Suddenly Saroo SWOOPS DOWN and discovers her - SAROO (CONT’D) (like a lion) Roaargh!! - and Shekila shrieks her delighted lungs out too. Such a beautiful release of energy. Then another ROAR from behind, and it’s Kamla, playfully catching the two of them off-guard.  57 They all tumble and wrestle, squealing, laughing. Sound o the leaves crunching, the wind in the trees... Shekila notices on her arm - a ladybird. The tiny delicate insect. Sound of a bird call, clear, in forest canopy. She and Saroo watch the ladybird, entranced... INT. SAROO’S STUDENT APARTMENT - CONTINUOUS The sounds of play and forest trail into Saroo, now sitti up on the edge of the bed. Staring into the darkness. His head racing, his heart pounding. He breathes. JUMP CUT: Saroo is standing now. In the dark. Just standi there. He stares over at his laptop. Something’s calling He sits at his desk. A haunted look. Hits ENTER. The scre saver opens to his default page, Google. ON SCREEN: - he types “Indian train station water tanks” as a search A hodgepodge of results, as you’d expect. Assorted images water towers. He clicks on a couple. It’s not that none look like the o in his memory. It’s that they all look fairly similar. In the search bar he types “Dams India”. Again, a mixed bag of random results. IMAGES of giant hyd electric works. He clicks on an aerial shot of one. In the bottom corner of the image, he notices: - a logo. “Copyright Google Earth”. Curious, he clicks on it. Google Earth opens. The address bar: www.google.com/earth ON SCREEN: that now-so-familiar Google glow - our Earth - beautiful blue sphere suspended in pure black space. To either side of it, the menus and controls. Saroo stares at it all. How does this work? Using his track pad, he clicks the arrows. The globe “spi Slowly at first. Working out how it works. Then around th curve of the planet comes India - that familiar triangle was on his wall all of his childhood. He stares at it. As if it might give him some information  58 [Note: during all such scenes we're INTERCUTTING BACK AND FORTH between Saroo and screen. ] He hits the “plus” symbol and starts to zoom inwards agai At a certain point he spots Calcutta (or “Kolkata”, by 20 Down, down. Closer. The Earth coming closer. SAROO’S “MEMORY MAP”: 1 - WATER TOWER (NIGHT) The looming WATER TOWER, that night on Burhanpur platform [NOTE: these memory maps are Saroo’s vivid, clear memorie the landmarks that will act as his geographical “locators SAROO’S “MEMORY MAP”: 2 - DAM (DAY) WIDE: the DAM, the long dam wall. Two little silhouettes (Guddu, Saroo, distant, frolicking) emerging from the wat SAROO’S “MEMORY MAP”: 3 - UNDERPASS (DAY) WIDE: Little Saroo runs into the distinctive UNDERPASS ne Khandwa Station. SAROO’S “MEMORY MAP”: 4 - ALLEYWAY TO HOME (DAY) We FOLLOW over little Saroo’s shoulder, sprinting down th narrow alley to home, past the house with the lurid aqua wall, past the overflowing bougainvillea.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: Ammi! Ammi! INT. SAROO’S STUDENT APARTMENT - CONTINUOUS On the screen - Saroo sees the great river - the Hooghly, can see it’s called - that slices Calcutta in half, much Paris or London. The river, closer. We can make out crowded city blocks no

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: The bridge ... There it is. The Hooghly Bridge. And there: Howrah Statio

dialogues.speaker: SAROO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No way. His emotions up in his throat. ON SCREEN: the floating label says “Howrah Station”. Ther is. All the platforms. All the tracks leading out. Saroo, in awe, devouring all this visual information.  59 Now, inches from the screen. TINY JUMP CUTS: Saroo squinting at the specks on the platforms: each speck a person, but LO-RES, GRAINY, COARS Something hypnotic about it - the graininess, the little circle spinning as the pixels clarify and sharpen. Saroo hunched over, rapidly mastering these controls. Learning how to scroll and “track”. He scrolls along the tracks leading out from Howrah Stati But now - remembering - he imagines what it must have bee like for his brother - to find him missing -

dialogues.speaker: IMAGINED MEMORY, PLATFORM, BURHANPUR STATION
dialogues.text: The out-of-focus stretch of the empty Burhanpur platform, four in the morning. C/U Guddu walks up into frame, into focus. The moment tha sees that Saroo is not there. His panic surges.

dialogues.speaker: GUDDU
dialogues.text: Saroo?! SAROO?! His panic rising, he runs, searching, continuing to screa INT. SAROO’S STUDENT APARTMENT - CONTINUOUS Guddu’s SCREAM (AUDIO) trails into the beginning of this scene, as we find Saroo overcome by those screams. His he racing. His heart pounding. His breath catching in his ch

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Are you okay? He nods. Switches off the computer. This is too hard. She’s sitting up in bed, watching him. Her great, dark ey Her tangle of dark hair. She’s a goddess. He dives back into bed, back into the sensuality, the physical warmth, the miraculous present moment.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: I am now.

dialogues.speaker: HIGH ABOVE HOBART
dialogues.text: Gliding HIGH above beautiful Hobart: across the waters of wide Derwent River, as we come across the city itself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old-fashioned beach house right on the sand. Outdoor stairs lead up to the front door, which is on the first floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saroo’s in the shower. Singing to himself. Saroo and Lucy’s home - nothing expensive but evidence everywhere of care, taste, and a nesting impulse. Saroo dries himself. Towel around his waist. Walks into t bedroom. Starts up his laptop. ON SCREEN: India. He scrolls randomly along a railway track; then stops at STATION. The laptop struggles to render the image - the rotating h glass spins and spins... Saroo looks frustrated - his old laptop is crap. Lucy hurries in. All dressed up. Corporate. Sparkling.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: Wow. Look at you. She does a spin. SAROO (CONT’D) Your hem’s down...

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: (panics) Oh God. It’s so long since I wore this. (beat) Have you got a stapler? He gets one. Staples her hem for her. She notices the computer struggling to render. Says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: (reassures her) They’11 love you. He starts kissing her neck.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: I haven't got time... Saroo keeps kissing her, nuzzling - Lucy reciprocates.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: 61 Saroo’s alone - eating toast - dressed in his Assistant Manager’s suit - name-pin on his lapel. He returns to the laptop - the hourglass is still spinnin He’s incredulous - shakes his head in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow Saroo (in a suit) into a large convention room which is at this moment bursting with activity. The space is filled with STAFF setting big round tables w perfectly starched table cloths, vases, table numbers etc

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: Peter - have you got the individual place cards too?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I’m on it.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: (to another worker) Michael - take three people with you to the loading dock. The flowers have arrived. Michael heads off. Saroo stands there surveying his domai CLOSE: he shifts his tie, stretches his neck. We suddenly how uncomfortable he looks. Something not quite right. He starts striding FAST out of the convention room -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - and suddenly we’re behind LITTLE Saroo (same camera ang as he follows a scene of utter CHAOS as three POLICEMEN d screaming Guddu to a paddy wagon - - Shekila wailing in Saroo’s arms, Guddu kicking and screaming, Kamla grabbing at the policemen - - as they spill from inside the home to the alley outside

dialogues.speaker: GUDDU
dialogues.text: Ammi! Ammi! [Mummy! ]

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: Guddu!

dialogues.speaker: KAMLA
dialogues.text: You can’t arrest him! Kamla lashes at the policemen - we follow behind Saroo as they drag Guddu up the street to the waiting wagon -  62

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - and now ("REVERSE” of previous shot) we LEAD, tracking backwards, as Saroo picks up speed - striding towards us - and STOPS. Panting. Looks around. Generic hotel doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STILL LIFE: an empty high-end hotel room. The door knocks

dialogues.speaker: SAROO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Housekeeping. (beat) Housekeeping. The door opens. Saroo enters using his swipe card. He sits on the sofa. Still breathing hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neighbors are gathering at their doors and windows, watch the commotion, as the police drag Guddu from the door to paddy wagon, Guddu resisting, Saroo and Shekila distresse

dialogues.speaker: KAMLA
dialogues.text: Guddu!

dialogues.speaker: GUDDU
dialogues.text: Ammi! SLAM! They bundle him, struggling, into the paddy wagon. fingers through the grille, his terrified eyes looking ou

dialogues.speaker: KAMLA
dialogues.text: He hasn’t done anything wrong -

dialogues.speaker: HEAD POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: - he was caught stealing eggs - Kamla starts screaming, Saroo, still holding Shekila, ste to the paddy wagon door.

dialogues.speaker: GUDDU
dialogues.text: Saroo! Saroo is shell-shocked, his big brother being taken away. is numb, trying to process it. But Kamla is positively fe As she screams and keeps kicking up a fuss, we’re CLOSER Guddu and Saroo:

dialogues.speaker: GUDDU, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Saroo! Listen to me. Pay attention! Saroo crying, focuses on Guddu, nods bravely Okay.  63

dialogues.speaker: GUDDU, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Whatever happens, you need to be strong - nothing can break us if we stick together - Kamla rattles the paddy wagon door, fearless, feral.

dialogues.speaker: KAMLA
dialogues.text: Arrrrggghh! ...

dialogues.speaker: GUDDU
dialogues.text: I’m talking about Ammi. You understand? Saroo nods, Yes.

dialogues.speaker: GUDDU, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look after her, Saroo! Don’t let me down. This is all we have. We stick together -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saroo walking it off, pacing. He shakes it out of himself Get a grip. Time to get back to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside the prison, in the shadows, Saroo sidles up to a barred window:

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: (whispers) Guddu! Guddu! - - he whistles a short coded whistle. The coded whistle comes back, from ten feet further along There’s Guddu, at the next bars along. Beaming.

dialogues.speaker: GUDDU
dialogues.text: Brother - Little Saroo proudly gives Guddu some tomatoes he has sto Guddu devours them, ravenously, urgently - keeping his ba to the MEN in the cell (B/G).

dialogues.speaker: GUDDU, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where did you get these? Saroo merely grins.

dialogues.speaker: GUDDU, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You’re my hero.  64 Saroo couldn’t be prouder.

dialogues.speaker: GUDDU, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But you have to go! They will catch you! I’1l be out soon! Go! Go to Ammi! Go quickly! Saroo nods, runs. He is his brother’s hero. We follow little Saroo for a time. Sprinting his heart ou Gliding through the dark Indian night. Running. Running. INT. SAROO & LUCY’S LIVING ROOM - VERY LATE NIGHT Saroo is now lying on the couch - laptop on his belly - t SOUNDS of his running fading from the previous scene. An ever-so-slight smile on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music hovers. Empty dawn streets, eerily interesting. And still. Not even the birds are up yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the dawn light, Lucy walks into the living room, dress for a run. She finds Saroo, passed out on the couch, laptop still op on his belly. The neatly piled list of stations and other search paraphernalia on the floor. For a moment she looks concerned. Then she moves the lapt off him - without looking at the screen. Wriggles onto th couch, next to him. He groans.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Time for a run... Saroo’s eyes open - his face says “You must be kidding me

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saroo and Lucy run up a steep mountain track. Both hung-o for different reasons. But a combination of natural beaut fresh air and endorphins is kicking in. Lucy pulls ahead - Saroo grabs the back of her T-shirt to hold her back - she’s laughing.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Oh my god - you are such a bad loser!  65 Saroo manages to race past her. Claims victory - we can s in him the same little kid from Wineglass Bay.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: We're BEHIND Saroo and Lucy, who are perched on a viewing spot. Stretching in front of them: Spectacular, expansive, glorious GREEN. And OCEAN beyond. They're so HIGH UP, it’s like a Google Earth view. Lucy looks utterly content. Closes and opens her big blue eyes - we see this panorama through her eyes in all its expansive glory. Saroo’s eyes are wide open too - focussing - - it’s the same view as Lucy’s - but not uninhabited - Saroo’s POV: in the distance, the tiny figure of Guddu. What’s Guddu doing here, on Mount Wellington? In the land the living? Guddu’s silent stare calls to Saroo... Lucy - smiles at Saroo - realizes he’s not here, with her the present moment. She looks disappointed. Worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saroo is in the bedroom. He’s having a panic attack. Trie slow his breathing.

dialogues.speaker: MEMORY, KHANDWA QUARRY
dialogues.text: Kamla stands in the moonscape. She seems to be staring straight at Saroo...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy comes in.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Sweetheart? It’s after six... Saroo squeezes his eyes shut. As if he could somehow bloc out the present.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: Fine.  66 INT. SUE’S ART STUDIO, BRIERLEY HOME - NIGHT CLOSE on small, beautiful watercolors - ethereal landscap horizons - stacked around, as Sue and Lucy step into the downstairs sun-room/studio.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: I don’t usually show anyone these -

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: They're beautiful ...

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: I do have fun. My secret hobby. Lucy notices, on a shelf, a jumble of trophies. At a glan there seem to be about ten different sports here, from so to windsurfing to cricket.

dialogues.speaker: SUE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Saroo’s. He was good at everything.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: I had no idea.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: He was such a happy boy. Lucy looks away. Spots a framed family photo, picks it up gently.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Wow, look at Mantosh. ON PHOTO: Saroo, Mantosh, Sue and John laughing on the bo

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Yep. He was a cheeky little thing... Lucy gazes closer at the snapshot of a lost, happy era. SUE (CONT’D) Pure energy. Impossible to control. But incredible. If he could ever learn to control it, he could do anything. Saroo’s very protective of him. Lucy’s finding this conversation a little difficult. She so many questions she’d like to ask Sue, about Saroo’s childhood.

dialogues.speaker: SUE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’ve been blessed...  67

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saroo on the deck with John, who’s just stacked some fres cooked chops on a plate. Sausages sizzling away on the gr

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Not partying too hard? Saroo, amused by that.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: Not partying at all!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You look a bit tired.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: It’s just work.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: How’s it with Lucy?

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: Great.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: We love Lucy.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: (entranced by the sausages) Yep. It’s hard not to. She’s great. Pause. SAROO (CONT’D) I’ll get us another beer. Saroo turns inside. John nods. Okay. Prods the meat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saroo steps inside. And Mantosh is there, back turned, rolling a cigarette as he props the fridge door open with leg, inspecting the contents. He turns as he hears the sliding door.

dialogues.speaker: MANTOSH
dialogues.text: (nervously) Was wondering where everyone was. His eyes are BLAZING STONED. Saroo takes him in.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: Jesus. You couldn’t be a little more wasted?  68 Mantosh shrugs, grins. Aloof bravado, but fragile underne Just holding on: clearly it’s a big effort just to come h At that moment Sue comes up the stairs with Lucy. Is very happy to see Mantosh.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Darling -

dialogues.speaker: MANTOSH
dialogues.text: Mum! Sue goes - tentatively - to hug him. Mantosh somehow mana to balance the half-rolled cigarette as she enfolds him. Through the awkwardness, it somehow becomes a warm embrac

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: (private, in his ear) Well done for coming. She breaks the embrace -

dialogues.speaker: SUE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is Lucy ...

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: (very friendly) It’s nice to finally meet you. Mantosh continues to roll his ciggie, licking the paper.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: (nervous to confront him) You have to smoke that outside. Mantosh lights the cigarette, takes a deep toke.

dialogues.speaker: MANTOSH
dialogues.text: No worries. He heads outside to the deck. Saroo, fuming, can’t stand Mantosh does. He notices Sue, now readying the food in a fussy and manic way.

dialogues.speaker: MANTOSH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey, Dad!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Son! ON Lucy. Okay. Right. She feels the world, between them a in that cigarette smoke. All the spaces in between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saroo, Lucy, John and Sue at the table, serving up. A dar cloud building over Saroo.  69

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: (to Saroo) I saw all your trophies...

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: Oh Mum, you didn’t? -

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: (re: Saroo) He never tells me anything about growing up -

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: That's just half. I’ve got more in the garage.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: (re: Saroo) These days I can’t get him off the couch.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: (warns) Luce -— Sue, John and Lucy quite taken aback by his sudden intens

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Why can’t you tell them what you’ve been doing? -—

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: - don’t -

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: - what’s that, luv? —- Mantosh enters, even more stoned, rubbing hands, big grin

dialogues.speaker: MANTOSH
dialogues.text: Yum, dinner! He sits. Notices the tension. And it’s not from him!

dialogues.speaker: MANTOSH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What? What have I missed?

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MANTOSH
dialogues.text: (noticing Lucy) She looks upset.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: She’s not upset.  70

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: (to Saroo) I can speak for myself. And how do you know how I feel? In his stoned amazement, Mantosh enjoys the spectacle.

dialogues.speaker: MANTOSH
dialogues.text: Saroo knows everything. He’s an expert. He’s a manager.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: Why are you here?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: He’s here because he’s your brother.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: No he’s not. We're different. So cold, matter-of-fact. For Sue, a knife in the chest. F John, an alarm-bell - it’s never been easy but this open aggression is new. Mantosh goes from stoned amazement to hurt. He looks rattled, vulnerable, and five years old. H stares at Saroo, a deep wound opening in him. SAROO (CONT’D) (awkward, but can’t stop) Every fucking meal you do come to, you have to get wasted -

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Now, now -

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: (to Saroo) How dare you. Mantosh gets up - not coping - starting to become wild - - John stands to soothe him - he knows this routine -

dialogues.speaker: MANTOSH
dialogues.text: (so wounded) - I wouldn’t want to be your brother, mate — John cradles Mantosh, tries to talk him down. Mantosh las out - a verbal lashing too, semi-coherent. John doesn’t l go - handles it as he always has - whispering the mantra Mantosh’s face -—

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: C’mon. Breathe. Big breaths. You're okay. Shhh. Shh. You’re good, luv. You're good.  71 Mantosh continues muttering, distressed. Quite the show f Lucy - 25 years of history in a minute.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Boys... Mantosh breaks free, heads out the door - John follows -

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: No - Mantosh - it’s all good, shh - John leaves in pursuit, he throws a glance back at Saroo

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: - nice one, mate - Sue looks to Saroo: if looks could kill.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: I hate what he does to you! Silence. Sue turns to Lucy. Lucy is trapped - she hates lying, but she has to be loyal to Saroo. Sue looks disappointed in her. Lucy - mortified.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: (to Lucy) I see. (to Saroo) Whatever it is, I’m warning you, I can’t do it. Sue and Saroo - locked together. O.S, AUDIO: fragments of John pleading ("Come on, mate, c back inside,” etc). Mantosh’s car starting. Sue’s silence circles Saroo, like a shark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s silent. Lucy’s just woken up. She’s in bed, alone. Saroo’s pillows - neat. No sign he’s been in bed beside h Lucy - lost in her thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy walks into the living room, wearing Saroo’s old T-sh She opens the curtains. Sunrise floods the room. Saroo locks eyes with her vulnerable, searching stare.  72 He shuts the laptop - nothing here he wants to talk about holds her gaze. Almost defiant. Yep. I’ve been up all nig Yep. This is what I’m doing.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Why don’t you want your parents to know?

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: They've got enough to deal with. You saw what Mantosh does to them. It’s always about him. Ever since he got off the plane.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: They’d support you. They’d understand.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: They'd pretend to. Mum’d keep smiling even if she was dying inside.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Because she wouldn’t want you hurt. She wants to protect you. She’s a mother. Beat. Saroo, so mad, so sleep-deprived, turning sour on L Whose side is she on?

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: Wait. Do you even want me to find them?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Of course I do. But I’m worried about you. (beat) About us. He walks into the kitchen. Leaving Lucy stranded. INT. LUKE’S PLACE - NIGHT Saroo and Lucy arrive at a party in a terrace house. Loud music - a narrow, packed hallway - a crush of PARTY GUEST They greet their FRIENDS, including Luke - the host. Saro all smiles. Loud and cheerful - over-playing it. Lucy's aware of his hyped-up mood - concern in her eyes. INT. LUKE’S LIVING ROOM - CONTINUOUS A short time later, Lucy is dancing. Saroo’s drinking. Looking around. Disconnected.  73 She beckons to him. He ignores her. Wanders out. She keeps dancing. EXT. LUKE’S BACK YARD - NIGHT Lucy searches out Saroo, who - uncharacteristically - has found a corner to be alone in. She stands in front of him. He doesn’t look at her. How l will he actually ignore her? She moves closer - takes his hands - places them on her b under her shirt. He pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: I need a beer. As he starts to move past her, she loses it. Blocks his p

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: (furious) “I need another beer.” You always do that -

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: Stop it, Luce -

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: - no, you stop it! There are party guests nearby - Saroo and Lucy keep their voices low, neither of them welcoming a public drama. But now Saroo disengages, infuriating her more.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where are you? He shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: (on the public setting) I’m not prepared to argue with you.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Talk to me. Be with me.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: Can this wait till we get home ... The more he tries to avoid conflict, the angrier she beco  74

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Home? You mean the place I live, alone? With you - alone - in the next room?

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: Luce -

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: I moved here to be with you.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: - this isn’t working.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: What isn’t?

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: Any of it. He moves past her - INT. LUKE’S PLACE - CONTINUOUS - and back into the loud party - and out of here - - Lucy hot on his heels -

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Saroo! Luke, watching them head for the door. EXT. STREET OUTSIDE LUKE’S PLACE - CONTINUOUS (NIGHT) Saroo just wants to get away. Lucy follows.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Don’t do this.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: You don’t get it.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: You have to face reality.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: What do you mean, “reality”?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: The reality that you’re ruining your life! That you’re not even here!  75

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: Do you have any idea what it’s like, knowing my real brother and mother spend every day of their lives looking for me?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: (genuinely bewildered) What?

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: How every day they scream my name. (beat) And I feel their touch. I see their faces. Can you imagine the pain they must be in, not knowing where I am? Twenty-five years, Luce. Twenty-five!

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Why haven’t you ever told me this was happening?

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: And we swan about in our privileged lives. Pretending. It makes me sick. Lucy is speechless.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: (faint, soft) I never stopped you ... It’s as if Saroo suddenly sees her pain properly. And is brought back to earth. The air in him deflating.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: Listen -. Lucy -. I’m sorry -. I can’t do this -. (beat) You deserve more -

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: - don’t! Don’t you dare. Her eyes fill with tears.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is on you! Not me. Saroo can’t deal with her pain. He takes off. This time, doesn’t follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saroo walks the streets like a tormented soul.  76 He can’t live in two worlds at once. He has to choose. Slowly, his despair becomes defiance. He’s made his choice.

dialogues.speaker: IMAGINED MEMORY, KHANDWA STREETS
dialogues.text: Kamla wanders the streets, distressed.

dialogues.speaker: KAMLA
dialogues.text: Saroo! (JUMP CUTS.) She’s beside herself. Searching empty lanewa

dialogues.speaker: KAMLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Saroo! Saroo! Faces everywhere. Kamla looks like a crazy lady. People peer out from their windows and doorways. She neve stops, the camera always moving. A mother in panic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First hints of light. Saroo just wandering. He seems drained. All movement, no thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kamla is by the river, amongst the prayer, the smoke, the chanting. Kids in the river, swimming. Washing. She hunts their faces.

dialogues.speaker: KAMLA
dialogues.text: Saroo! WIDE: she searches in this enormous landscape - strange, poetic, haunting - the PEOPLE like ants ...

dialogues.speaker: KAMLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Saroo! Her voice drowned out by the sound of a train, passing ov the river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO MONTHS LATER. SOUND of the sea. Bright marine light. track through the house. It’s virtually empty. The atmosp of a squat. No sign of homeliness, of warmth - of Lucy. A mattress on the living room floor. A master map of Indi the wall. Piles of print-outs - lists of railway stations some marked-up - most still pristine. Images of water tow train platforms, under-passes. Saroo - long hair, beard - has surrendered to his obsessi MUSIC starts - continues into a series of HARD CUTS: - Scrolling; waiting for the pixels to resolve. - A blue “train station” symbol. - CLOSER IN: a formless, satellite-image town. - On Saroo: studying its features. No, that’s not it. He stands - grabs a blue pin - sticks it into the map. - leans back into the screen. Reads the next town - - enters the name. - blue train station symbol. - Another town, the surrounds of the train station. - He grabs another blue pin - sticks it into the map. - Scroll. Symbol. Station. Pin. - Scroll. Symbol. Station. Pin. It becomes a rapid MONTAGE. Sound of someone hammering on front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mantosh is at the door. He looks nervous, desperate, stan there counting coins in his hand. He bangs harder on the door.

dialogues.speaker: MANTOSH
dialogues.text: Saroo, ya bastard! Silence. Mantosh, listening.  78

dialogues.speaker: MANTOSH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Saroo! (beat) Mate, can you lend us fifty bucks? CLOSE on Mantosh, sweating there at the door. He doesn’t good. Mantosh gives up knocking, leaves.

dialogues.speaker: MANTOSH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yeah, whatever, dude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saroo spies out of the window. As Mantosh heads off down the beach, he’s joined by a DRU MATE, who has been lurking somewhere near. The mate looks to Mantosh, inquisitive, Well? Mantosh jus shakes his head, No go. They walk away. Saroo turns. Guddu is there, also watching Mantosh. Saroo and Guddu look at each other. Saroo returns to his search.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO MONTHS LATER. Saroo - his hair longer, his beard wild moves slowly down the aisle of a stationery shop - puttin boxes of COLOURED FLAG PINS into a basket. He’s out of place in this vivid Charlie & the Chocolate Factory world. He stops at the pen section, testing high-lighters. Throw some different-coloured boxes of those in his basket. At the counter, as the items are scanned, we study Saroo’ face. He looks exhausted. Doesn’t notice when the CASHIER smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: Same project? Saroo nods, with an air of defeat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saroo walks along the sand with his shopping. Past rows o suburban houses, their blank windows reflecting the sea.  79

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little Saroo on the tracks, proudly holds his pregnant be of coal. Guddu bustles over to him.

dialogues.speaker: GUDDU
dialogues.text: Come on, hurry. Little Saroo looks so happy, as they trot off together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saroo crosses the sand to the house. His face determined

dialogues.speaker: I/E. TRAIN CARRIAGE, INDIA
dialogues.text: Saroo’s POV: the world moves past in a watercolour blur - ochre country, hills, mountains, trees -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON SCREEN: tracking railway lines, flying above them - station after station. Saroo ZOOMS in. His hopes up. He counts the platforms with his finger. NO: yet again, that’s not it. Disappointed, he zooms back out. GOOGLE SCREEN JUMP CUTS: train track after train track .. Platform after platform... SOUND of a real train, approaching, coming under us:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kamla walks up to the very edge of railway track just as train rips past very fast. An endless stream of carriages - the noise and speed viol crazy, dangerous - but Kamla shows no fear.

dialogues.speaker: KAMLA
dialogues.text: Saroo! Saroo! Her screams drowned out by the racket of the train. She i hell, but cannot - will not - give up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saroo mirrors her desperation. He gets a beer, stares at map. A new colour being used now, for a new search zone. About 15% of the search complete.  80 He’s suddenly aware it’s the dead of night. He feels like only soul awake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO MONTHS LATER. CLOSE on a table filled with leftover Chinese food (where some people have just finished and le the table), when a SMALL INDIAN HAND comes into frame, th fingers scooping up the food - - we TRACK up the arm to reveal Guddu - wolfing down the with bare hands, greatly enjoying it - and all the while staring across to - - Saroo (other side of the food court) - who stares right back, sitting in front of his untouched (western) meal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saroo steps onto the escalator. The lights and muzak of capitalism definitely not working wonders for him. As he descends: there is someone ascending. It’s Lucy. Sh looks grounded and somehow resolved. They approach each other. Lucy sees him. Alarm in her eyes. He looks like a crazy m Saroo swings across, from his escalator to hers. As always, drawn by her vivid gaze, her intense life-forc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy follows Saroo up the stairs. She walks in and stops at the sight of Saroo’s “Project”. It’s mind-blowing. An entire wall is plastered in charts, train-timetables, station-name-lists, grainy images from Google Earth. On the Master Wall is a big map - surrounded by smaller o And all the pins ... The floor layered in books, notes, clothes, take-away containers. We go closer to the Master Wall with Lucy, inspecting it. Dense trails of colored drawing pins on the 400km search radius - different colors for different train lines. WALL KEY: green pin = Mumbai line, red pin = Nagpur line But our dominant visual information: in the past 6 months Saroo has covered a fraction of the search radius. The in circle only.  81 Saroo responds to Lucy’s look of fascination and alarm.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: Theoretically it’s not infinite. She just stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lucy - I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saroo and Lucy sit on the beach.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: What was she like?

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: Beautiful. He’s lost in the memory of it - staring out to the ocean, drawing patterns in the sand. SAROO (CONT’D) I’ve been visiting her. (beat) Every night I walk those streets home - home from the dam, home from the station. I know every single step of the way. And I imagine that I’m whispering in her ear. “I’m here. It’s all right.” Silence. Lucy knows what he means - she’s imagined the sa thing with her own mother. SAROO (CONT’D) How was New York?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Same old, same old.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: And now? Lucy grins. There is good news.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Our funding came through.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: That’s great! See, they know how good you are. An awkward silence.  82 Lucy can’t resist a moment longer - she reaches out and c his beard with her fingers. Her touch is like manna from heaven. SAROO (CONT’D) I miss you - A pained beat -

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: I saw your mom. She hasn’t been well. He doesn’t want to hear this.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: She'd freak if she saw me like this.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: You underestimate her. A long, sad pause.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She needs you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A monsoon day - in the middle of a torrential downpour. A MERCHANT (55) loads a giant WATERMELON into Saroo’s arm

dialogues.speaker: MERCHANT
dialogues.text: Hurry! Hurry! Hurry! Go! - the merchant keeping dry, looking for a gap in the traf launching Saroo onto the wet road, with his green boulder - Saroo, ill-prepared for the task, as traffic whizzes by almost immediately his feet slide out from under him - - and a MOTORBIKE blares out of nowhere, careening down u Saroo - too late - the motorbike brakes, skids, aqua-glid - SLAMS into Saroo - who sits up - YOW! - head bleeding, watermelon gloop all around him, as the motorcyclist kick starts his bike, and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saroo touches the blood - - blood in the puddle where he sits, blood on his hand -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saroo runs home through the rain, his shirt bunched to hi head, blood and rain streaming down his tiny torso -  83 - he runs into the UNDERPASS - we recognize this as one o the “Memory Maps” - and into BLACK -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kamla tends to Saroo’s gash. Saroo’s crying. Shekila’s wailing. Kamla wipes the wound with a cloth. Guddu enters, drenched too. It’s still pouring outside.

dialogues.speaker: KAMLA
dialogues.text: Where were you? You were meant to be looking after him! Guddu knows he messed up. He looks upset, ashamed. Saroo Shekila cry and cry. But now Kamla draws Saroo closer, and ever so gently she kisses his forehead better. His crying begins to subside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But now, it’s not Kamla who kisses it better. It’s Lucy - gentle, loving - kissing that old scar on Saroo’s forehea They've just made love - all those endorphins and oxytoci flooding their bodies - on the mattress on the floor. There’s an edge to it all: Saroo’s life still looks bache transient and obsessively preoccupied; Lucy is conflicted knowing she shouldn’t really have gone down this path. But god it’s nice, after sex: even with the floating sadn

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: That village might not even exist any more. Entire worlds change in twenty-five years. I worry that ... - but she lets it trail off, and hang.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: That what? Long, sad pause.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: That you’re chasing ghosts. She stands, pulls on her shirt. Smiles that brittle, pain loving smile at him. And his own heart is broken, because he knows he can’t do anything but keep on with that search. She opens the door, walks out.  84

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It could be later the same day. It could be another day. has blended into something amorphous. Saroo lies on his lonely mattress. All is still; even the sea is calm. Then past silently weaves into his consciousness, all these vignettes and flashbacks united in their stillness, as hi eyes flicker closed:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON KAMLA - unmoving, sensing Saroo;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON little AMITA, lying in bed, staring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON CAFE GUY - his kind stare through the cafe window (as Saroo sits on that traffic island, fantasizing non-existe food on his rusty bent spoon -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON WIRY BOY - just moments before he decides to offer the cardboard, dignity and generosity - then: INT. BEDROOM, NOOR’S ROOFTOP HOME, MORNING (FLASHBACK) ON RAMA - his slow-moving hand along Saroo’s leg ...

dialogues.speaker: RAMA
dialogues.text: You’re a good boy. Are you a good boy? (O/S AUDIO) Whimpering - a scuffle - shouts. A confusing auditory nightmare. Beatings. Cries of anguish. Rape. Lil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON HAUNTED BOY, swaying back and forth, rubbing his hair forehead, a pressure cooker about to explode. He bangs hi head against the wall, over and over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SOUND of Haunted Boy banging his head carries over in screaming and sudden pandemonium, as the CHILD-SNATCHERS arrive and the URCHINS scream and scatter and WIRY BOY is violently grabbed and wrenched away, screaming -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saroo’s eyes, still flickering. Guddu sits in the dark - dusk or dark now - watching over Saroo. Keeping his dista Giving Saroo space. He knows the memories are the search.  85

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A knock at the door. Saroo wakes and goes to the window. Looks down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, looking up. He has a “care package” from Sue. He pu it by the door. He waits. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: It’s the One Day International tomorrow. Come over if you like. We'll get some beer and pizzas. Nothing from inside the house. INSIDE: Saroo just stands there, pressed against the wall Frozen. Conflicted.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I meant to tell you - I fixed the tiller. Why don’t we take her out, head up the coast? Maybe see if we can round up Mantosh. Pause. John, listening.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Saroo, your mum’s not - Whatever he was about to say ("Your mum’s not doing so well”), he stops it. Looks down at the care package.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your mum’s made a nice cake for you. Put a few other goodies in here too. (beat) I think she’d love a visit. He stands there, hoping against hope that Saroo will sudd appear.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Right. Take care, son. He turns to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saroo sits on the beach, a starry night. Watching the wat the ghost-waves marking time like a pulse ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A night light in the kitchen illuminates Sue, standing at sink. Her arms hanging limp. Exhausted. Mute.  86 Five-year-old Saroo steps beside her. Reaches up, takes h hand. She snaps out of it, looks down on him. It’s all right, s the look on his face. A private communion. The son comforting the mother. Then, if remembering her duty to look after him, Sue pulls Saro close, cradles his head. They stand there, a silent tableau. INT. SUE’S ART STUDIO, BRIERLEY HOME - AFTERNOON Concern registers on Saroo’s face as he enters the little room. Sue sits in the weak sunlight by the window. She lo pale and unwell, in her dressing gown, nursing a cup of t Saroo doesn’t look crash-hot either - months of no sleep exercise have taken their toll. Two lost souls. But she brightens at the sight of Saroo.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: (hugging her) I’m sorry. I’m sorry. He sits opposite her. She holds back tears.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: John just heard, he’s been out on the boats. Doing the lobster run. They’re due back tomorrow. Saroo looks at her, doesn’t want to admit what this means

dialogues.speaker: SUE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So he’1l be flush for cash. And then back on the hard stuff ... Saroo can see in her pain how much she loves Mantosh. She smiles bravely, her pale eyes sparkling.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: I’m sorry you couldn’t have your own kids. ON SUE: a misconception, dawning on her.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: What are you saying?

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: I mean, we weren’t blank pages, were we? Like your own would have been. You weren't just adopting us, but our pasts as well. (beat) And I feel like we're killing you.  87 Sue smiles - still holding off the tears.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: We could have had children. We chose not to. ON SAROO: shocked by this new information.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: Wait. You could have had kids?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Never made that public. Some things need to stay private. Some people would never understand why you’d start a family like ours. We wanted you two in our lives. We chose that. Saroo is moved. Listening intently. SUE (CONT’D) (smiles, remembering) I think it’s one of the reasons I fell in love with your dad. (beat) We both felt the world had more than enough people in it already. Because to have a child - that’s no guarantee that’s going to make things better. But to take a child who's suffering - like you boys were - and to give him a chance in the world. Well, then. Now there’s something. Saroo looks with wonder at his mother. What she’s given u Without her, where would he have ended up?

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: I bet you never imagined it would be this hard.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: It’s not a matter of hard or easy. There was only ever one path. That’s how I believe things happen. (beat) When I was twelve, I had a vision. Some people would call it a breakdown ... Saroo, completely intrigued by his mother opening up like this - in such strange ways.

dialogues.speaker: SUE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know my father was an alcoholic. Out of control. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: SUE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All wrong. I remember I was weeping. Or I'd wept it all out. There were no more tears. I was standing out the back of the house. Looking out across this field. I literally wanted the earth to swallow me. There wasn’t any joy. Life was a nightmare. And I felt this kind of - electric current - electric shock - jolt through me. And there was a little brown- skinned boy across that field. I couldn’t even tell if it was just my eyes playing tricks. And then he was beside me. Just standing there. And I sensed it so strongly. I could feel his warmth.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Literally. The left side of my body started to heat up.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: Did you try to talk to him?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: It wasn’t like that. Anyway, I was doubting my sanity. Even as it happened.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: It didn't speak?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: It stood beside me. And for once in my bleak life, I felt something good. And I knew it was guiding me. And I knew - in my heart - I'd be fine. It was as if, at that moment, I could suddenly believe in the future. Saroo sits there, haunted and entranced by her story.

dialogues.speaker: SUE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And now - I don’t know where I’m going. I don’t know what anything means any more. I thought I could hold everything together. By an act of will.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: - oh, Mum -  89

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: But it’s all just splinters. Everything splintering off. Saroo, pained. He shrugs, palms up: I don’t know what to

dialogues.speaker: MORNING
dialogues.text: Way down there, Saroo’s car travels along the wild, lush, remote Tasmanian coast.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. CAR / NEAR DOVER LOBSTER PORT
dialogues.text: Saroo winds down towards a wild windswept inlet. Towards Mantosh’s shed... EXT. MANTOSH’S SHED - CONTINUOUS Saroo pulls up, gets out, bangs on doors. Peers in throug the windows.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: (calls) Mantosh! Wide: the lonely ghost gums echo his call. INT. SAROO’S CAR - CONTINUOUS He gets back in the car, to wait it out... the trees, the isolation... the quiet... relief almost... He winds his seat back. Stillness.

dialogues.speaker: KAMLA, (V.O., PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: That one is Makara, the sea monster. You see his long tail?

dialogues.speaker: SAROO, (V.O., PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: Ammi - if he’s a sea monster, can he fly?

dialogues.speaker: MEMORY, ROOFTOP, ONE-ROOM HOME, KHANDWA
dialogues.text: Looking DOWN on Kamla, Guddu, Kallu and Saroo (Shekila wrapped in swaddling, sound asleep), all lying on their b on the flat roof, looking up at the stars.

dialogues.speaker: KAMLA
dialogues.text: I don’t know. It’s as deep as the ocean up there. Pause. They’re all staring straight up, in wonder.

dialogues.speaker: KAMLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (gesturing) See the bright one, and the line like that? That’s Simha. The lion.  90

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: Will he eat us?

dialogues.speaker: KAMLA
dialogues.text: He might. When he gets hungry enough. ON Saroo: gazing up. Sheer wonder. Thinking about Simha. REVERSE - their POV. The incomparable spread of stars. INT. SAROO’S CAR - DUSK Saroo, looking up at the ceiling of his car. A single tear rolls from his eye. Gentle SOUNDS on the ro spitting of rain. BANG on the window - a wet and bedraggled MANTOSH, has ju pulled up in his UTE, waders over his arm, smoking a join

dialogues.speaker: MANTOSH
dialogues.text: Brother from another mother. Your hair looks as bad as mine. Saroo, sits up, gets out. Mantosh offers Saroo the joint. Saroo shakes his head No. Mantosh takes a big toke. Flicks the joint away. INT. MANTOSH’S SHED - CONTINUOUS Inside, it’s barely habitable. A grimy sink. A rickety ta A single bed with grey blankets that look damp. Mantosh pours cheap whisky into two grubby glasses. He tu the RADIO on low. They sit, clink glasses, take a sip. Mantosh’s cheery fac fails to hide his desolation and desperation. He holds his hand out, horizontal.

dialogues.speaker: MANTOSH
dialogues.text: I’m off the speed, mate. Perhaps his hand trembles, just a little; Saroo notices.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: That’s good. ‘Cos Mum’s not well.

dialogues.speaker: MANTOSH
dialogues.text: (wary) Oh yeah? What is it?

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: Stress. She thinks she’s gonna lose you - (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: SAROO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (quick adjustment: ) - us. She’s worried about us. It hangs there. Big thing for Saroo to say. Mantosh, taki it in. His heart shifts, a notch. His big brother just sp of them as an ‘us’.

dialogues.speaker: MANTOSH
dialogues.text: That’s no good.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: Nah.

dialogues.speaker: MANTOSH
dialogues.text: I should get out to see her.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: Yeah. Long pause. SAROO (CONT’D) I’m sorry for what I said at dinner. Mantosh shrugs, remembering. A silent, painful It’s nothi SAROO (CONT’D) You been all right? Just the act - the intention - of Saroo trying to connect breaks something open in Little Brother. Mantosh heaves a single sudden dry sob - then stops it. All the world’s pa in those shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: MANTOSH
dialogues.text: We were the untouchables. You know that, don’t you? You know how much our lives were worth. Nothing. Zero. (remembering: such pain) They had no problem touching me. He looks up at Saroo as if coming out of a trance.

dialogues.speaker: MANTOSH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You were one of the lucky ones. I’m not having a go at you. I’m genuinely happy for you.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: What do you mean, “luck”? - Mate, I think about my mother in India every day, knowing I’1l never see her again. Same as you.  92

dialogues.speaker: MANTOSH
dialogues.text: (smiling, but an edge) Not the same. I had bad luck being born. You got LOST! That’s all that happened, bro. And before anything bad even happened, you got whisked off to Australia. Do you know how long I was in Liluah for? Fourteen months. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: MANTOSH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Not untouchable in there. Silence. Saroo, staring at Mantosh. The “lucky ones”. He knows he’s got a point: at Liluah, Saroo escaped the bogeyman.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: What happened to you was bad. It was just bad. But this is not how you deal with it, Mantosh. You think I’m lucky; I think I made my own luck. I don’t know which one’s true. I didn’t have choices. When that train took off, I didn’t have a choice. You've got to keep going. Sometimes that’s all it is. Mantosh just looks at him. They both seem exhausted. SAROO (CONT’D) You've suffered enough.

dialogues.speaker: MANTOSH
dialogues.text: I’m persevering, bro. Trust me.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: I’ve already lost a brother. I don’t want to lose you too. (beat) I need you, bro. We gotta keep this family together. You and me. A light coming back into Mantosh’s eyes. Just hearing thi But then, too, the irony:

dialogues.speaker: MANTOSH
dialogues.text: We do things differently, you and me. You try to remember. I try to forget. Saroo is moved by his insight. They sit in silence in thi new, fragile camaraderie - the radio still playing low, B Mantosh stands at a song he likes. Turns up the volume. K Minogue’s I Can’t Get You Out Of My Head.  93 He takes a large swig of whiskey. A big smile spreads. He starts to dance to the music. His ridiculousness is infectious, and Saroo smiles too.

dialogues.speaker: MANTOSH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: C’mon, dance with your brother! Mantosh turns the volume up louder.

dialogues.speaker: MANTOSH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (over the racket) c'mon! Saroo reluctantly gets up. And dances. Two goofy brothers And then: they begin to lose themselves. The scene becomes loud, frenetic, crazy. They can’t belie they’re doing this. They’re laughing like mad.

dialogues.speaker: MANTOSH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (shouting in Saroo’s ear) I love you, Saroo. I’m gonna get better. Saroo grins, Okay, then. Good. Mantosh takes a big swig straight from the bottle. Passes it to Saroo, who does the same. Grinning. And now, they really do lose themselves. The dance is completely mad. And glorious. INT. MANTOSH’S SHED - DAWN DAWN. Saroo, wrapped in a blanket. Staring at his sleepin brother. The scars on Mantosh’s hands. The tobacco-staine fingers. The fragility. CLOSE: gently, carefully, Saroo places the old Ganesh medallion in the palm of Mantosh’s hand. He closes Mantosh’s fist around the medallion. EXT. PEBBLY BEACH NEAR MANTOSH’S SHED - DAWN Saroo steps outside into the freezing morning. No one abo Not a sound. Not a bird. Just the WILD WIND and the small gnarly steel-grey WAVES hitting the shore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saroo, a tiny figure, walks down to the water’s edge.  94 He strips off - and starts to walk into the water... stop as the pain of the cold kicks in... the endless horizon beyond. He looks back at the shed - Mantosh will not survive with him. He spots Guddu, looking vulnerable, worried, is he losing Saroo?... His locked stare with Guddu. A deep breath from Saroo - - Guddu looks alarmed, as if he wants to stop Saroo - - Saroo DIVES. UNDERWATER - fluid, peaceful, muffled. Saroo’s wild hair flowing. He comes up - roaring - oh, the shock! - his wild wet man

dialogues.speaker: ROAAAARRRGGHHH
dialogues.text: Roaring in pain. Grief. Anger. Knowing he can’t go on. Roaring his past away. BIG emotional moment, then in its wake... Guddu is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saroo steps up to the wall. All its madness in front of h He reaches for a flag pin. Pulls it out. What’s he doing? He stabs it back into the map - to a totally different pa of India. Way outside the search radius. Then with both hands, he starts pulling out flag pins, stabbing them anywhere. Jumbling them up. Pins everywhere There are pins now all over the place. Pakistan. The Himalayas. He’s just deliberately ruined a year or two of painstakin work. Making certain it’s over, and there’s no turning ba Casually, he SWIPES at a section of printouts spreading o from the main map, scotch-taped together. In a domino eff other printouts tear away. More flag pins go flying. A me He leans his head against the wall. Saroo slumps down on the couch. End of the road. He has t move on too. Over on the Wall: that mess he’s just made.  95 The laptop sits open on the couch. He leans across, place his finger on the trackpad, follows a train line - - then starts to flick the track pad, faster. So that bef the station has time to reach full resolution - - he flicks again, carelessly, without method. And suddenly - it’s a kind of goodbye - he veers off the line completely - out over land - and more land - - doing on the SCREEN what he just did on the WALL - - random shifts, here, there, left, right. Jerky. EVERYTH starts cascading in his psyche, as his memories make thei final fight for life. So we see MAD SNIPPETS and FLASHES: GUDDU - COAL THEFT - DAM - JOY - UNDERPASS - STREETS —

dialogues.speaker: WATERMELON ACCIDENT
dialogues.text: - and on and on it goes - interwoven with the Google Eart search on screen, as Saroo carelessly continues flicking cursor, saying goodbye to the search as his past and his memories disintegrate into fragments - He stops. Exhausted. His face perfectly blank. Equally randomly now, he tap-tap-taps on that “Zoom Out” minus si He ZOOMS OUT, higher. Higher. We’re now staring down on a good chunk of India. Scrolling, Saroo flicks quite a distance left. Still just random moves. We are now way outside the search perimeter Nothing matters. Flick, flick. Who cares? And then: something stops him. He tilts his head - ON THE SCREEN: an expanse of ochre fields. He pulls the laptop onto his thighs. Something about that COLOR. Still as the Sphinx, he stares at the screen.

dialogues.speaker: FIELDS
dialogues.text: - matching the Google Earth, but real: we’re hovering abo real ochre landscape. STILL. We can hear nature - the tickling of the grass, the whole earth vibrating. (NOTE: this shot should also recognizably MATCH the lands of the 4000-feet-above-India shot, those parched ochre fi from the opening AERIALS...] -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saroo shivers. The sound of the gentle wind over him. Jus staring at that screen.  96

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on little Saroo’s hand, scavenging through the tras at that moment the YELLOW BUTTERFLY lands on it. As he carefully stands, and spreads his arms: PANORAMIC WIDE of an ochre landscape. Full of yellow butterflies. The YELLOW is fluttering, fluttering, and starts FILLING FRAME. AUDIO: very faintly a haunting refrain rises: the lullaby little Amita sang that long-ago night in Liluah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lullaby carries over to the present - we’re back with Saroo - more ALERT - scrolling on the Google screen - We scroll over fields. Villages. Then a railway line. He does what he’s always done: trace the tracks to find t next station. - A FLASH: POV FROM MOVING TRAIN (from when he was trappe of those WIDE OCHRE FIELDS - He keeps scrolling, scrolling. And soon enough: the train line enters a mid-sized TOWN. We're over the centre of the town. He zooms in closer. The Google Earth blue railway station symbol, hovering. The rail lines. The platform. Closer in. Closer. And then, on Saroo: Huh. What’s that? ON GOOGLE EARTH SCREEN: it’s blurry. But it looks a littl like a water tower. Saroo blinks, looking at it. Zooming in. His head tilts: - this water tower, getting a little clearer as he zooms. SAROO’S “MEMORY MAP”: FLASHBACK 1 - WATER TOWER (NIGHT) Little Saroo alone on the deserted platform. Where’s Gudd Saroo shivers, holding himself. He looks up. At the tower

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saroo, sitting up straight. Looking as spooked as that ch  97 ON SCREEN: it’s a WATER TOWER. It’s certainly similar. Saroo leans in closer to the screen. His finger touches t platform. And the water tower. Working out the angles. SAROO’S “MEMORY MAP”: FLASHBACK 1 - WATER TOWER (NIGHT) We PUSH IN on little Saroo, standing frightened on that haunted platform, looking up at the water tower off-scree REVERSE: we PUSH IN on the water tower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON SCREEN: zooming, closer, closer. The satellite resolut becoming clearer. That’s a tower. That’s the water tower. The pixels coarsen and blur as the zoom reaches its limit

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: (a breath) It can’t be - Saroo actually cups his hands over his mouth. His back is ramrod straight. His nerves on fire - - and suddenly, frantically, he scrolls, scrolls, scrolls

dialogues.speaker: OCHRE FIELDS
dialogues.text: High in the air, we RUSH across the Indian landscape -

dialogues.speaker: GLIDES
dialogues.text: - ON GOOGLE EARTH SCREEN: as he scrolls, the pointer race across the landscape in jerks: across ochre fields, acros rivers, roads ... sometimes the train line is on screen a sometimes not - because Saroo’s not following the track n he knows where he’s going - - he’s going HERE: - it’s a DAM. Holy shit. It’s a dam. SAROO’S “MEMORY MAP”: FLASHBACK 2 - DAM (DAY) Guddu’s POV: we’re spinning in a circle, holding onto Sar with outstretched arms as he too shrieks with laughter. WIDE of same: Guddu twirls Saroo around in the shallow wa by the dam, tiny Saroo’s feet barely skimming the surface Guddu lets go, Saroo flies into the water. He jumps up, laughing. Drenched in golden sunlight.  98

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saroo’s hands are shaking. Fingers on the track pad, urge This cannot be happening. He zooms in closer. ON Google Earth screen, more details: clay shore, the LONG DAM WALL. SAROO’S “MEMORY MAP”: FLASHBACK 2 - DAM (DAY) - a beautiful, sun-drenched moment: five-year-old Saroo sprinting homewards, the dam receding behind him (with it LONG DAM WALL). Elation and urgency mixed together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saroo keeps scrolling, paying 1000% attention. ON SCREEN: he stops on the town. Saroo, scrolling. Eyes attentive to every detail. ON SCREEN: the name hovering above the town is “Khandwa”.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: (it doesn’t ring a bell) Khandwa?... But his fingers trace across the screen. There’s the STAT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little Saroo continues running home, past Khandwa Station

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saroo, scrolling along - - ON GOOGLE EARTH SCREEN: the UNDERPASS - SAROO’S “MEMORY MAP”: FLASHBACK 3 - UNDERPASS (DAY) Little Saroo continues running home - into the underpass

dialogues.speaker: JUMP CUT
dialogues.text: - and pops out the other side -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saroo, scrolling frantically. Nose inches from the screen ON GOOGLE EARTH SCREEN: we scroll OVER the underpass - ou the other side - following roads -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - left, right, right - the roads getting narrower ...  99 And now, at last: a NAME floats above this part of town.

dialogues.speaker: GANESH TALAI
dialogues.text: ON Saroo: what?? WHAT                        ! ON SCREEN: there it is. Floating. “Ganesh Talai”.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: Ganesh Talai. Ganesh Talay. Ganestlay. He gasps. Then an involuntary LAUGH comes from deep in hi belly. A feeling that this can’t be happening. And now he picks up speed, and scrolls, ever faster - - ON SCREEN: the streets, narrower and narrower —

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little Saroo, sprinting, lungs bursting, joyful, homeward

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - Saroo, glued to the screen. Scrolling. Left, right. The streets getting narrower. ON SCREEN: a street so narrow it could only be an alleywa SAROO’S “MEMORY MAP”: FLASHBACK 4 - ALLEYWAY TO HOME (DAY We FOLLOW over little Saroo’s shoulder as he rounds the f corner to the narrow alley to home: past the house with t lurid aqua walls, past the overflowing bougainvillea -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON SCREEN: We stop. Above a nondescript CLUSTER OF SHACKS We ZOOM, closer, closer. Towards a single specific BUILDI Closer. Until the pixels coarsen, and the roof is a blur. Saroo, breathing hard. Staring so intently at the screen. That blurry, pixellated roof fills the entire screen. On Saroo, brimming with emotion.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: (very softly) Ammi ... - that Hindi word, rising up from the deep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saroo knocks. Lucy comes to the door. They stare at each other. She looks frightened - what’s happened...

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: I found home... Her face - doubt, belief, joy for him. Did you just say w I think you said? Saroo’s eyes, wide in amazement. That’s a Yes. Lucy wraps her arms around Saroo. They embrace tightly - what does this mean for them? Held in that embrace - rocking gently together - Saroo breathes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saroo holds the door open as Sue walks into the room. John, just arrived in his work clothes, stands there, pro as punch - watching his wife.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You need to look at this - Sue enters slowly, mesmerized by something off-screen. Emotions palpably rippling across her face. REVERSE: we follow her as she walks up to the map - it’s still in disarray from Saroo’s flag pin destruction, but can see how amazing and methodical it was. Sue studies it. The grandeur, the scope, the epic madness even in its fractured state. Its magnificence. ON Saroo: watching her, anticipating her response.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: This is where you've been? He nods.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: I didn’t want you to feel I was ungrateful... Sue takes it all in, astonished.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Saroo. She embraces him, overcome with emotion.  101

dialogues.speaker: SUE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I really hope she’s there. She needs to see how beautiful you are. John joins in the embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saroo in his window seat on the plane. Peering out, down the dark earth. Most everyone else is asleep, and the lig are dimmed. But Saroo’s awake, and deep in thought. And just like that five-year-old - twenty-five years ago, heading off to the unknown - he pulls the shade down, up. only once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We’re back in our mythic, prehistoric, dust-shrouded landscape. The washed-out whiteness. The white dust. And again, Saroo running across the sun-baked rubble, whi with dust himself. Everything so heightened and surreal.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: Ammi! Ammi! He’s carrying something close to his chest, like a bright orange heart. He’s beaming, proud. SAROO (CONT’D) Ammi! And there in the distance, Kamla turns again. Shading her eyes against the sun. Covered in the white quarry dust. SAROO (CONT’D) Look what I’ve got! He reveals his offering: in the middle of all that white perfect, bulbous MANGO. Glowing in its perfect orangeness She reaches out her hand. Touches his face in thanks. Wha unimaginable treat.

dialogues.speaker: JUMP CUT
dialogues.text: Saroo and Kamla sit on the rocky ground, devouring the ma The juice streaks their dust-caked faces. Sucking at the flesh, the nectar. A playful delight coursing through the SAROO (CONT’D) I threw a rock. I knocked it out of the tree!  102

dialogues.speaker: KAMLA
dialogues.text: (grinning, nodding) Good boy.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. TAXI / ROAD FROM INDOOR TO KHANDWA
dialogues.text: Saroo in the back seat of the taxi. Peering intently out window at the landscape rolling by. The fields. The small towns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We FOLLOW CLOSE behind Saroo as he enters his hotel room throws the backpack on the bed. Saroo at the window. Looking down on the bus terminal and further away - train station from this third floor room. POV: all the mad activity down there in the streets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saroo lies fully clothed, spread on the bed. Shoes still Arms spread. Staring up at the ceiling. He’s wide, wide awake. The ceiling fan turning. No way he getting twelve hours’ sleep.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: All right. He leaps up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saroo walks along the busy street. Hard to read his face. Past the busy station. And suddenly now in front of him: UNDERPASS. He strides ahead. His legs carrying him forwar now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saroo strides along the road. Purposeful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saroo knows exactly where he’s going. Automatic pilot thr those never-forgotten streets. Turning left. Turning righ Now he RUNS - as he did through these streets as a child. EXT. ALLEYWAY TO SAROO’S CHILDHOOD HOME - MINUTES LATER Saroo turns into a narrow alley. Heart positively poundin He rounds the next bend and -  103 - stops dead. From BEHIND, his view down the ALLEY, past that house wit those (now faded) lurid aqua walls, past the overflowing bougainvillea: we recognise that long-ago childhood home. REVERSE of this: looking at Saroo. Only it’s 5-YEAR-OLD-S who’s standing there now. Still as a statue. Awed. Little Saroo starts moving forwards, towards home. We tra backwards with him. He’s not scared, just calm, amazed. H been waiting for this moment for a long, long time. He arrives at the door - HARD CUT to side angle: now it’s ADULT Saroo, peering in through the rotted slats of the door - And ... it’s abandoned in there. His POV: in there, in the gloom, there’s NOTHING. That di floored shack, the rubble of a former life. He steps back. So that’s it. Shit. Stands there, at a los

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (in Hindi) Can I help you? Saroo turns. It’s a WOMAN, 21, with a BABY in her arms.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: Hi! Um - I used to live here. (off her blank look) You don’t speak - ? (pointing at the shack) I used to live here. He unfolds a sheet of paper. ON THE SHEET: it’s an enlarged photocopy of that photo ta at the police station when he was five. SAROO (CONT’D) That’s me. I used to live here. The woman nods politely. But can’t understand a word he s A middle-aged MAN pokes his head out from a doorway.

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH-SPEAKING MAN
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: Hello. You speak English?

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH-SPEAKING MAN
dialogues.text: Yes. A little.  104

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: Have you lived here long?

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH-SPEAKING MAN
dialogues.text: Some time.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: (pointing at photo) I’m Saroo. This is me. (pointing at empty house) I'm looking for, um. Kamla, Guddu, Kallu, Shekila. The man looks from Saroo to the house. To Saroo.

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH-SPEAKING MAN
dialogues.text: Here? You lived here?

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: Here. Yes. The man takes a long look at Saroo. Squinting.

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH-SPEAKING MAN
dialogues.text: Wait here. And he simply turns, and walks away. Saroo: every nerve ending is alive. We CIRCLE him. Everyt else a background BLUR - chatter in Hindi, PEOPLE popping of doorways. And Saroo staring down the alley to where that man just disappeared around a corner. Where has he gone? Saroo starts walking, as in a dream, toward the corner. The people trailing him. But we’re CLOSE with Saroo. Momentarily, the man reappears around the corner. ENGLISH-SPEAKING MAN (CONT’D) Come.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: Come where?

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH-SPEAKING MAN
dialogues.text: (he’s already moving) Come. They walk. Saroo in his trance. Rounding the corner - Saroo, the man, the curious HANGERS And fifty metres ahead, there are THREE WOMEN standing th stunned, uncertain. Two of them flanking the ONE IN THE MIDDLE, lightly holding her by the elbows.  105 Behind them, their own entourage of curious HANGERS-ON. On Saroo: brain about to explode. This can’t be real. Can As Saroo and entourage move towards the three women, the three women and entourage begin to move towards him. PUSHING IN towards the women: to that one, CENTRE OF FRAM Kamla. A quarter of a century older. Still as beautiful. REVERSE - PUSHING IN towards Saroo, as he walks towards u On Kamla: with immense confusion and reservation, staring at this giant man, this total stranger. - and as she gets closer, looking into his eyes -

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: Ammi - - and she knows it’s him.

dialogues.speaker: KAMLA
dialogues.text: Sheru! They embrace each other, tightly.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: (close, soft) I’m sorry. I’m sorry. They hold the embrace. Then Kamla starts running her hands over Saroo’s face. SAROO (CONT’D) It’s me - (showing her the photo) Look - The instant Kamla looks at the photo, it ALL comes back, she weeps. Hugging Saroo, wailing, touching his face. The commotion growing. PEOPLE appearing. Explanations fly

dialogues.speaker: JUMP CUT
dialogues.text: The little crowd has grown further. Everyone talking at o Kamla can’t stop hugging Saroo, touching him, squeezing h

dialogues.speaker: A NEIGHBOR
dialogues.text: Are you sure it’s him?

dialogues.speaker: KAMLA
dialogues.text: (stabbing the photo) It’s him. I know it’s him. My son has come back.  106 She reaches up, parts the hair on his forehead. Sure enou the scar.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: The watermelons!

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH-SPEAKING MAN
dialogues.text: (in Hindi) Watermelons.

dialogues.speaker: KAMLA
dialogues.text: The watermelons!

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: (in Hindi, imitating) Tarabuja! [Watermelon] (beat) And Guddu? Where is Guddu?

dialogues.speaker: KAMLA
dialogues.text: (heartbroken) Guddu. Guddu. Saroo, not wanting to believe what he thinks she’s saying

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH-SPEAKING MAN
dialogues.text: Guddu is no more. (beat; clarifies) He is with God. Amidst all this surreal joy, a knife in the heart. Saroo looks at the man - numb and uncomprehending. He looks to Kamla: is it true? Surely it’s not true. In her eyes: it’s true. It’s true. Such sorrow. They embrace. She weeps. AUDIO muffles - they’re in some private space that sound can’t penetrate. They gaze into other’s eyes. Pain, love, joy - Then: a COMMOTION. The crowd parts for ADULT SHEKILA (27)

dialogues.speaker: KAMLA
dialogues.text: (she’s nearly hysterical) Shekila! It’s him! (to Saroo) This is Shekila! This is your sister! Saroo, amazed.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO
dialogues.text: Shekila? Kamla nods yes; a howl of joy from Saroo -  107 SAROO (CONT’D) Shekila! He pulls her into the embrace. The onlookers crowding and touching him, as if he’s not r Saroo and his mother and sister, locked in the embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That last night together, twenty-five years ago: little Saroo, King of the World, perched on the handlebars as Gu pedals for all he’s worth through the streets of Khandwa. They're gliding. Banking. Soaring. The world is rushing b

dialogues.speaker: A YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Go, Guddu! It’s as if they’re being cheered through the very streets SMALL FADE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saroo - a profoundly changed man - at the window, looking over Khandwa and the train station. The street stalls, the lights, the endless traffic. SUE’S PHONE MESSAGE (V.O.) Hello. You've reached Sue Brierley. I can’t get to the phone right now, please leave a message.

dialogues.speaker: SAROO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hi Mum. I know you’1l be sound asleep. (MORE ...)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The warm late sun floods the air as we come upon adult Sa walking along the water’s edge by the dam, where a new generation of KIDS are splashing and playing - just as Sa used to do, twenty-five years ago.
